Award.AwardTitle: EBEE: Enhancing Bioscience and Engineering Education through Curriculum Integration and Research Experiences in Systems Biology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NC A&T) will initiate a five year project to develop new institutional strategies to Enhance Bioscience and Engineering Education (EBEE) through curriculum integration and research experiences for undergraduates. Specifically, the project team will build a model of integration between the engineering and biology programs at NC A&T, focusing on the interdisciplinary field of Systems Biology. The project will integrate several STEM academic programs in the College of Engineering and College of Arts and Sciences and multiple ongoing NSF and non-NSF funded research projects, while capitalizing on recent complementing University level initiatives.

To support the project, a university-wide interdisciplinary cluster of faculty, staff and students will be established by the Provost to broaden collaboration among bioscience and engineering disciplines. The cluster will include members of the project team and representatives from the wider university community with specific interests and background in the life sciences, systems biology, computational methods and engineering.

Fifty (50) undergraduate students in engineering and biology will receive stipends as well as a supplemental award for research materials or for travel expenses to participate in local and regional conferences. The students will be co-advised by two faculty members from different disciplines and from different funded project teams. The research projects will be in systems biology, an emerging interdisciplinary field that spans the interest areas of the participating projects and allows the University to explore greater collaborations among a number of STEM faculty. This collaboration will be built on a common platform using SimBiology (TM), an integrated environment in MATLAB (TM) for modeling biological processes, and analyzing the models with simulation and experimental data. Two major curricular development activities will be carried out to achieve this goal. One involves the expansion of the general education core curriculum for all undergraduates, but those in biosciences and bioengineering in particular. The other is aimed at building meaningful bridges among the engineering and biology programs through an accelerated BS-MS program in bioengineering.

Intellectual Merit
The project will introduce new areas of research to faculty and graduate students through their involvement with undergraduate research projects that focus on the emerging interdisciplinary field of systems biology. Furthermore, the project will develop a new model of university-level integration of research-intensive departments and lead to strengthened and integrated multidisciplinary curricular options for students.

Broader Impact
The project will help to recruit and retain a larger number of qualified underrepresented STEM students who will contribute to the scientific community through cutting-edge research and scholarship.

The award is being awarded through the Innovation through Institutional Innovation program and is jointly funded by the Division of Human Resource Development and the Directorate for Engineering Office for Diversity and Outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The disproportionately low numbers of African American students graduating from bioscience-related disciplines reflect a complex interplay of numerous socio-economic forces. There are many factors to consider relative to academic performance of students in the minority community that are quite different, such as family backgrounds, expectations, learning styles, and instructor effectiveness. Therefore, personal intervention is required from key people at all levels of a student’s academic path, including but not limited to parents, professors, and administrators. The goal of the NSF I3-sponsored Enhancing Bioscience and Engineering Education through Curriculum Integration and Research Experiences in Systems Biology (EBEE) program at North Carolina A&T State University was to help students develop an awareness of college-level academic and social requirements, as well as institutional and peer resources available to them, in order to promote student success at the interface of biology, engineering and mathematics. This required mentoring with conscious awareness of obstacles that inhibit students from participating on the path toward growth between the classroom, laboratory, and entry into graduate school. To that end, we viewed undergraduate research as a catalyst for student development across gender, ethnicities and disciplines. Significant undergraduate research participation, coupled with the opportunity to participate in scientific research conferences and workshops focused on success at the undergraduate and graduate levels, has been integral contributors to the success of our model for success. Combined with a strong focus on mentoring, our program has fostered the joy of systems biology-related research in women and minorities and serves as a model for other programs focused on increasing the number of underrepresented minority students who graduate and persist in bioscience-related disciplines.
